Project Number: 46083 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
September 2012 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Improving the Institutional 
Framework for Environmental Statistics 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country programming mission in Manila in 
December 2011, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested ADB to 
provide policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to help the Ministry of Environmental 
Protection (MEP) in enhancing the environmental statistics institutional framework. This TA was 
then included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2012–2014 for the PRC.1 In March 
2012, an ADB mission visited the PRC, and reached an understanding with the government on 
the  TA  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  costs  estimates  and  financing  plan,  implementation 
arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. The TA design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Environment statistics describe the qualitative and quantitative aspects of the state and 
changes of the environment, and their interaction with human activities and natural events. 
Environment statistics are integrative; they measure human activities and natural events that 
affect  the  environment;  and  they  monitor  the  impacts  on  the  environment,  and  the  social 
responses to environmental impacts. It is an emerging statistical field in official statistics in most 
countries  and  is  indispensible for  evidence-based  policies  and  decision  making to support 
sustainable development.3  
3.  The  PRC’s  environmental  statistics  system  was  established  in  the  1980s  and  has 
evolved significantly. The system quantitatively summarizes the PRC’s industrial and urban 
pollution protection and prevention, environmental management, and capacity development for 
environmental protection systems. The October 2011 State Council’s opinions on ―strengthening 
priorities of environmental protection‖ emphasized the need to (i) improve statistics for the 
emission reduction monitoring and evaluation system, (ii) encourage implementation of the 
major pollutants’ emission control, and (iii) establish an environmental information resource 
center that will enable environmental statistics and information works to meet higher standards. 
These statistics play a big role in management and environmental protection decision making in 
the PRC, which contributes to sustainable development.  
4.  Pollution  sources  have  changed  markedly  with  PRC’s  rapid  social  and  economic 
development. Environmental management approaches and requirements have also evolved to 
an extent where the existing environmental statistics system can no longer support them. The 
current  system  for  environmental  statistics  is  unable  to  provide  sufficient  coverage  of  all 
pollution  sources,  and  as  a  result  statistical  techniques  and  methods  for  environmental 
management are still weak. The PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan 2011–2015 emphasizes that the 
support for agricultural pollutants’ control statistics is still insufficient, and that the application of 
environmental data and comprehensive analysis is quite weak, which makes it difficult to meet 
the needs of policy analysis.  
5.  ADB provided TA to the government in 2005 to help develop the regional supervision 
centers (RSCs) of MEP (then the State Environmental Protection Agency).4 In 2009, ADB 
provided additional TA on Strengthening Enforcement of Environmental Laws and Regulations,

2   
which aimed to improve the enforcement capacity of national, regional, and local environmental 
agencies.5 The  TA  projects  progressed  hand-in-hand  with  the  government’s  institutional 
development and mutually benefited each other. The TA workshops and seminars provided      
effective fora to discuss the mandates, functionality, and staffing of the RSCs, while these RSCs 
were being established through parallel government efforts. The proposed TA will build on the 
achievements of past ADB projects, and draw lessons from these TA projects to support MEP’s 
efforts  in  improving  the  institutional framework  required to  (i)  improve  the  effectiveness  of 
implementing the existing environmental statistics system, and (ii) ensure that environmental 
statistics can be effectively used for supporting environmental management.  
6.  Building on the key findings and recommendations of the past initiatives, the government 
requested ADB to provide TA to help MEP (i) improve the institutional framework for the PRC’s 
environmental statistics, and prepare a detailed action plan in this regard; and (ii) prepare 
technical guidelines on accounting methods for livestock-related pollutants. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.    The  TA  will  contribute  to  improved  environmental  management  and  sustainable 
development in the PRC by supporting the country’s process of environmental statistics reform. 
The expected impact of the TA will be enhanced environmental monitoring and management in 
the  PRC.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  an  improved  environmental  statistics 
institutional framework in MEP.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Output  1:  A  review  of  international  experiences  in  environmental  statistics 
systems and livestock-related pollution accounting approaches prepared. The TA will 
review  international  experiences  in  environmental  statistics  and  reporting.  The  following 
suboutputs will be produced as part of this output:  
(i)  a summary of international experience in data collection, reporting, verification, 
quality  assurance  control,  data  application  and  analysis,  and  institutional 
arrangements,  including  the  supporting  legal  and  policy  framework  for 
environmental statistics; 
(ii)  a summary of accounting methods for livestock-related pollutants from different 
Asian countries, with subsequent recommendations for the PRC’s accounting 
system for agricultural pollutants; 
(iii)  a  review  and  synthesis  of  international  environmental  data  analysis  and 
application, 6  and  environmental  statistics  management  from  major  Asian 
countries,  resulting  in  recommendations  for  the  PRC’s  environmental  data 
analysis and application system; and 
(iv)  a final report that incorporates suboutputs (i)–(iii) and makes recommendations. 
 
9.  Output  2:  A  detailed  report  and  implementation  road  map  for  an  improved 
environmental  statistics  institutional  framework  in  the  PRC  prepared.  Based  on 
development trends in international environmental statistics systems and the results of the pilot 
                                                
5  ADB.  2009.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Strengthening  Enforcement  of 
Environmental Laws and Regulations. Manila (TA 7386-PRC).   
6  This will include information on types of policies and decisions that have benefited from the application of 
environmental statistics data.

3 
testing,  the  TA  will  propose  the  PRC’s  future  environmental  statistics  system  improved 
institutional  framework.  The  TA  will  also  prepare  a  detailed  implementation  road  map  for 
enhancing the environmental statistics system, and clarify short-term objectives and long-term 
tasks. The objective of this framework will be to outline the detailed procedures and steps for 
environmental statistics reform. The framework will address in detail the relevant technical 
standards, regulations, and provisions for each step of the cycle of the environmental statistics 
system (i.e., from the preparation to its application for environmental management). The TA will 
produce a policy brief summarizing the key recommendations for an improved environmental 
statistics system in the PRC. 
10.  Output  3:  Technical  guidelines  on  accounting  methods  for  livestock-related 
pollutants  prepared. Specific suboutputs related to the preparation of technical guidelines 
include  
(i)  draft technical guidelines based on international and national experiences;  
(ii)  detailed  accounting  methods  for  major  livestock-related  pollution  parameters 
(i.e., chemical oxygen demand, total nitrogen, total phosphorus, and ammonia);  
(iii)  detailed reports of  the pilot studies;  
(iv)  technical training sessions on accounting methods for livestock-related pollutants 
and environmental data analysis and applications, with target groups to include 
local environmental protection bureau staff, and the management of selected 
livestock farms; and  
(v)  finalized  technical  guidelines  on  accounting  methods  for  livestock-related 
pollutants. 
11.  The TA will implement the pilot project in selected locations (Ma’anshan, Anhui Province; 
Sanming, Fujian Province; and Zaozhuang, Shandong Province). MEP is developing detailed 
criteria for the selection of pilot project sites. The pilot projects are anticipated to take about 6 
months to be completed. The results of the pilot projects will form the basis for development of 
the technical guidelines on accounting methods for livestock-related pollution. MEP will seek to 
establish partnerships with city-level expert institutions when implementing the pilot projects.7 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $450,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and their 
travel and per diem, office facilities, domestic transportation, workshop costs, administrative 
support, and other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 
2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from 1 November 2012 to 30 April 2014. 
MEP will be the executing agency. A TA management office will be established in the Foreign 
Economic Cooperation Office (FECO)  of MEP to carry out day-to-day TA operations. The 
director of the Project Management Division 1 of FECO will serve as the executive director of 
                                                
7  Partnership with relevant expert institutions will be established once the target cities for the pilot projects have been 
determined.

4   
the TA management office responsible for coordinating day-to-day operational matters among 
ADB, consultants, and related government agencies.  
 
15.  A  TA  consultative  committee  will  be  established  to  provide  guidance  on  project 
implementation issues. The committee will be led by MEP’s Department of Total Pollution 
Control. This committee will comprise the general director and two directors of the Department 
of Total Pollution Control, a director of the Project Management Division 1 of FECO, and a 
director  from  the  National  Statistics  Bureau.  MEP  will  provide  in-kind  contributions  of 
counterpart staff time; cofinance the costs of international workshops and/or conferences, and 
printing costs; and provide logistical support, office space, consultants’ use of internet, and other 
basic office facility usage.   
 
16.  It is estimated that the TA will require 6 person-months of international and 28 person-
months of national consulting services. Four national consultants (an environmental statistics 
and institutional specialist and/or national team leader, a livestock-related pollution data analysis 
and accounting specialist, a statistical research methodologies specialist, and an environmental 
institutional and policy specialist); and two international consultants (an environmental statistics 
and institutional specialist and/or deputy team leader, and a livestock-related pollution data 
analysis and accounting specialist) will be required for TA implementation. The consultants will 
be engaged by ADB through a firm following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a 
quality–cost weighting ratio of 80:20. The biodata technical proposal approach will be used. 
Disbursements under the TA will be done following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Operational expenses for training, workshops, 
translation,  and  printing  will  be  included  in  the  consultant’s  contract.  Advance  contracting 
procedure for the engagement of consultants for the TA may be considered. The outline terms 
of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Improving the Institutional Framework for 
Environmental Statistics, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a firm 
following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality–cost weighting ratio of 80:20. 
It is estimated that the technical assistance (TA) will require 6 person-months of international 
and  28  person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  Four  national  consultants  (an 
environmental statistics and institutional specialist and/or national team leader, a livestock-
related  pollution  data  analysis  and  accounting  specialist,  a  statistical  research  and 
methodologies specialist, and an environmental institutional  and policy specialist); and two 
international consultants (an environmental statistics and institutional specialist and/or deputy 
team leader, and a livestock-related pollution data analysis and accounting specialist) will be 
required for TA implementation.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference  
2.  Environmental  statistics  and  institutional  specialist  and/or  deputy  team  leader 
(international,  3  person-months).  The  specialist,  with  knowledge  in  best  practices  in 
development and applications of environmental statistics systems, will support the national team 
leader. The specialist will have (i) an advanced university degree in environmental science or a 
relevant field, with at least 5 years of international experience in environmental statistics-related 
work,  reporting  approaches,  and  institutional  arrangements;  (ii)  basic  understanding  of  the 
environmental statistics system that is operating in the People’s Republic of China (PRC); 
(iii) experience  and  understanding  of  environmental  issues  with  on-the-ground  working 
experience in the PRC; and (iv) demonstrated experience in similar assignments. The specialist 
will have the following specific responsibilities: 
(i)  work together with the team leader; and refine the overall study framework and 
outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(ii)  conduct a review of international environmental statistics systems, particularly 
those relating to data collection, reporting, verification, quality assurance control, 
data  application  and  analysis,  institutional  arrangements,  and  the  supporting 
legal and policy framework;  
(iii)  summarize experiences related to environmental data analysis and application, 
and environmental statistics management from major Asian countries; 
(iv)  work closely with the national environmental statistics and institutional specialist;   
(v)  contribute to drafting, review, and editing of the inception, interim, and final TA 
reports to enhance the quality and presentation of the reports; 
(vi)  participate in TA workshops (inception, interim, and final) and other seminars 
presenting the TA progress and results; 
(vii)  prepare a draft policy brief (knowledge product) with recommendations on reform 
of the environmental statistics system in the PRC based on the study and TA 
final report; and  
(viii)  provide input to other related technical tasks as requested by the team leader. 
 
3.  Livestock-related pollution data analysis and accounting specialist (international, 
3 person-months). The specialist, with knowledge in best practices in accounting and data 
analysis of livestock-related pollution, will support the national team leader. The specialist will 
have (i) an advanced university degree in agricultural science or a relevant field, with at least 
5 years  of  international  experience  in  livestock  related  pollution  data  analysis,  reporting

10  Appendix 3 
 
approaches,  and  institutional  arrangements;  (ii)  good  understanding  of  and  experience  in 
livestock-related pollution issues; and (iii) demonstrated experience in similar assignments. The 
specialist will have the following responsibilities:       
(i)  work together with the team leader and refine the overall study framework and 
outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(ii)  prepare draft technical guidelines and methods for accounting livestock-related 
pollution based on international and national experiences; 
(iii)  provide guidance to the preparation of the criteria for selection of pilot projects, 
design, and implementation of the pilot projects;  
(iv)  provide input to the reports of the pilot projects;  
(v)  provide input to the content and design of the training material prepared for the 
various target stakeholders; 
(vi)  contribute to drafting, review, and editing of the inception, interim, and final TA 
reports to enhance the quality and presentation of the reports; 
(vii)  participate in TA workshops (inception, interim, and final) and other seminars 
presenting the TA progress and results; and 
(viii)  provide input to other related technical tasks as requested by the team leader. 
 
4.  Team leader and/or environmental statistics and institutional specialist (national, 
8 person-months).  The  team  leader  and/or  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  the  overall 
coordination and supervision of the TA activities and outputs, and day-to-day liaison with MEP 
and other national government agencies supporting the related work. The team leader and/or 
specialist should have (i) an advanced university degree with an environmental statistics and/or 
economics background and at least 5 years of experience with the PRC environmental statistics 
system;  (ii)  demonstrated  experience  in  project  management  and  team  leadership;  and 
(iii) English language proficiency and demonstrated experience in compiling technical reports 
and other relevant outputs similar to what is expected in this TA. The team leader and/or 
specialist will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)  develop  the  overall  detailed  study  framework,  consulting  with  the  executing 
agency, key stakeholders, international specialists, and other experts; 
(ii)  act as main liaison between MEP and the consultant team; 
(iii)  manage  and  ensure  the  timely  implementation  of  the  TA,  including  overall 
coordination of the various expert inputs; 
(iv)  lead the detailed design and implementation of the study, including the drafting of 
the proposed policy and institutional framework of the environmental statistics 
system for the PRC; 
(v)  compile and finalize various TA reports, including inception, interim, and final 
reports; 
(vi)  participate and present relevant topics during project seminars and workshops;  
(vii)  compile  and  finalize  the  TA  final  report,  and  coordinate  inputs  from  the 
international consultants; 
(viii)  manage  and  ensure timely  implementation  of  the  project  activities,  including 
inputs from various consultants; and 
(ix)  assist the executing agency in coordinating potential public relations issues. 
 
5.  Livestock-related  pollution  data  analysis  and  accounting  specialist  (national, 
7 person-months). The specialist should have an advanced university degree in agricultural 
science or a relevant field with at least 5 years of experience in livestock-related pollution data 
analysis in the PRC. The specialist will have the following responsibilities: 
(i)  work together with the team leader; and refine the overall study framework and 
outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports;
